Reviews.Content: If you're looking for luxurious, spacious accommodations go to the Ritz. If you're looking for an inexpensive, clean bed then Riverside Tower is for you. The rooms are small. VERY small. In fact I'd highly recommend upgrading to a "suite" which gives you two (albeit teeny) rooms. One with a double bed, sink, bureau, TV and one with a single bed, bureau, TV, small table and two chairs. These are linked via a toilet/shower room. But the location...OH! the location. This is the Upper West Side at its best. A wonderful safe residential area with some lovely apartment buildings just one block west of Broadway at W80th beside Riverside Drive which features a park that runs the entire length of Manhattan. Heading east, is Broadway itself with Zabar's on the corner - eat in or take out from the over 300 varieties of cheese, deli meats, breads, rugelach, ready-made sandwiches, Nova lox on a bagel, fruit salads or pain au chocolat. Artie's Diner is one block up (their all-day brunch menu is divine!), numerous diners, cafes, restaurants plus the subway (#1 Line) one block south. If you need even more green space, two blocks west and you're into Central Park. The Museum of Natural History is within walking distance as is The Met. I wouldn't hesitate returning to the Riverside Tower Hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Needs more than a lick of paint !”
Reviews.Author: UKJohnH
Reviews.Content: Very low end budget hotel, as previous reviews comment, small rooms, peeling wallpaper, ultra basic decoration and a new one, noisy radiators. On the upside is the location and cost ($119 plus tax). In this place you do really get what you pay for. If you are travelling on a shoesting I guess it would just about do. You pay on check-in, and the receipt says full refund within 20 minutes if you want out. However, do have a Plan B if you decide it's not for you, this is a residential area, with few ( if any) hotels in the immediate vicinity.

Reviews.Title: “Clean, safe, 'dorm room' feel”
Reviews.Author: MarySunshine53
Reviews.Content: My girlfriend and I visited Riverside Tower Hotel over the second weekend of March 2007. I will admit I was a bit worried when I read some of the reviews, but the place was really very nice for the price we payed ($140 per night all taxes included). We booked a suite with two single beds (which we found out were only available on 6th floor and lower). I was pleased to see a nice view of the Hudson through the trees of Riverside Park. The suite had two small rooms adjoined by a bathroom with a marble floor. We each had our own room which had it's own sink, dresser, and TV. One room had a table and two chairs as well as a refrigerator and microwave. The other room had the telephone. Although the rooms were small, there was enough room for us to walk around comfortably and set out our luggage. And there were NO bugs: everything was very clean, including the shower. The suite definitely had the feel of a dorm room: some peeling plaster, some writing on one of the doors, and a rainbow sticker on one of the mirrors. Also the rooms had old time heaters with a knob to adjust the level, but you could also open the window if you preferred. The rooms felt warm and comfortable for a cold March day. The beds were also comfortable and I was very impressed with the insulation between our suite and the other rooms next to ours. I have paid $300 a night for a room in NYC where I could clearly hear talking in the next room. We did not experiance that. We could hear the traffic out of the open window, but not to the point of annoyance. The location overall was wonderful, expecially since my girlfriend used to live very close to were this hotel is located. This hotel holds an exceptional track record of no crime in all it's years and I believe it! We were just two blocks away from Zabars and their cafe was a great place to grab a meal. Also, down Broadway towards 76th Street is a place called Nick's Burger Joint & Pizza Joint where all the "locals" go for good food at a reasonable price. They have almost any food/beverage imaginable including ostrich burgers, fresh squeezed orange juice, and gyro sandwiches. We went back three times. All in all, I would definitely go back to the Riverside Tower Hotel for an economy stay in the Big Apple.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect budget hotel!”
Reviews.Author: RoundAssTour
Reviews.Content: Like I'm sure many of you reading these reviews are wondering "Is this place REALLY ok to stay in?" Well, let me assure you, YES, it IS! This was my first trip to Manhattan and I've always wanted to stay in the Upper Westside because I am completely in love with this neighborhood. So many charming shops, restaurants, parks and very convenient to EVERYTHING as far as public transit goes. We were out walking around at 6am when it was still dark out and again at 10pm, had no problems with safety issues. It isn't as "lively" as the midtown area, so if it's round the clock action you want, this may not be the neighborhood for you. The rooms were clean, though small. We had a two room suite for two people and it was just fine. Sheets & towels were clean, though the beds were a bit small. The elevator is SMALL, just enough for two people and one or two luggage - but it got us to and from our room all week long with no delays. The front desk staff was very friendly. We will stay here EVERY TIME we return to NYC! For $100- $125 a night, you really CAN'T beat the price. Similar rooms in nearby hotels run at least $100 more to get a private bathroom. Save your money and stay an extra few nights :)

Reviews.Title: “hey, its a budget hotel”
Reviews.Author: justabubba
Reviews.Content: A good budget hotel. Rooms are small. Walls are thin. Amenities like shampoo or hair dryers don't exists. But all we wanted was clean and convenient and it was both at a good price. Some staff were helpful. Some were not. A real international clientele added to the experience. Safe area of the city makes coming home late easier. We will go again without hesitation and dream of the day when we can afford something more.

Reviews.Title: “Warning! this place could scare you for life!”
Reviews.Author: spongebobpatrick
Reviews.Content: I had a lucky escape as I did not stay in the hotel as I looked at the room and left. You wouldnt put a rat in it. it must GO against all health and safety legislations. DONT GO THERE. Our you will surely be scared for life.

Reviews.Title: “Don't do it!!”
Reviews.Author: NoMind
Reviews.Content: We visited The Riverside Tower Hotel with an open mind having read some "sketchy" reviews. Don't........it really is that bad! It is a very, very run down place. We took one look at the room, demanded a refund and stayed at a lovely hotel (for a simalar price) on 77th Street.

Reviews.Title: “tiny tiny rooms”
Reviews.Author: Carol_Suzan
Reviews.Content: You may not want to stay here unless you've enjoyed living in Manhattan or Tokyo. We wound up in a "suite." My daughter's room had a twin bed, fridge, microwave, phone, table, and two chairs. My husband and I had a double bed in our room, which was not substantially bigger than the bed itself. Both rooms had sinks, dressers, closets, and TV's. The two rooms were joined by a little bathroom consisting of a toilet and a small shower stall. We didn't use our dressers. In retrospect, I'm not sure I would have been able to open the drawers of our dresser, which was right next to our bed. I do recall needing to move into the most spacious part of our room to pull on a pair of knee-high winter boots. What's more, there were no deadbolts or chains for the doors. As a native New Yorker, I was spooked by their absence. While the neighborhood is great, I expect this level of security in most hotels. The rooms were variably climate controlled by either adjusting the knobs on the steam radiators or opening a window (in December). We stayed one night, and I doubt we could have tolerated anything more than that. The big upside was the $50M view of the Hudson River visible through the broken Venetian blinds of my daughter's corner room. In fairness, the hotel was clean, the staff were civil, and the elevators functioned. However, if you're from out of town, you'll probably have a panic attack in one of the elevators--they're not real big either. I'd be hard pressed to recommend this hotel to anyone but college students and other intrepid young travelers. However, they won't have the money to stay there, and would likely fare better at the hostel on 103rd and Amsterdam. The room my husband and I shared would have been downright dangerous for elderly guests.

Reviews.Title: “We bailed out!!”
Reviews.Author: deltagal
Reviews.Content: A friend had recommended this to us, and I called before booking. The person on the desk was very helpful, and nice. I knew the neighborhood and thought it would be a great location, also quiet. However, we stayed about 30 minutes -- just long enough to find another hotel -- and left. We had been given two very small single rooms joined by a bathroom (not what it looked like on the web). The carpet looked filthy. The hall way was very narrow, and I worried about emergency exits (when we got off the elevator we had trouble negotiating the hall because the cleaning crew had piled trash bags in the hall; there was nowhere to walk. It was the most depressing place I had ever seen. I have stayed at both the International Youth Hostel on Amsterdam and 94th, and the West Side Y, and they are much better -- and much cheaper -- that the Riverside Tower.

Reviews.Title: “Heart of Upper West Side”
Reviews.Author: gmgs
Reviews.Content: Had concerns about staying at this hotel after reading reviews. Our experience was ... Fabulous. Our first weekend visit to NYC. GREAT location. Two minutes to subway, bus line, taxi or limo service, everything close -- and I mean everything from coffee shops to grocery stores (Zabars) to high end restaurants... Beautiful views of the neighborhood, the Hudson, and Riverside park, QUIET wonderful quaint street. Yes -- the rooms are small, bathrooms and elevators are tiny, but in NYC property is a premium. We had a clean room, a comfortable bed and enough room for 4 of us. We parked free on Riverside Drive, rode the subway day and night. If you need the amenities of a Hilton -- then go stay at the Hilton... we enjoyed every minute of our stay at this hotel -- and we will stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Worst Hotel Ever”
Reviews.Author: PHILI
Reviews.Content: Dirty, smelly, would not board my dog there. Then to top it off they made an error on reservations so instead of 2 "suites' they only had one reserved..we fortunately found another hotel in same location..a bit more but so much better. I can't even imagine putting my head and body on the furnishings. Pay the extra money and avoid this hotel AT ALL COSTS!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Great location -safe residential area”
Reviews.Author: traveler63
Reviews.Content: After reading all other testemonials , we were bit sceptical and expected the worse , but i suggest go by your instinct and budget if you looking for cheap , decent place to stay for weekend this hotel is IT ,but do spend $10 and reserve suites as double rooms are really , really small,sheets were clean, beds comfortable to sleep on and shower power the best , no you don't need flip flops to take shower and no any bug eencounterss:-)and area is great, you are actually min walking from Broadway which will take you all the way down town even walking -that is if you are in shape to walk a few miles. It is really safe , residential area and very quiet at night , just as described ....lot of nice restaurants in the area but must mention Zabar- great breakfast place with great cup of coffee and delicious fresh baggels, just what you need to start your day and that is minuts away from the hotel so , yeah if you are budget minded traveler and want to to save few dollars and spend on something else , this is decent place to stay for short stay

Reviews.Title: “Not the Ritz, but good, affordable shelter”
Reviews.Author: ttlms
Reviews.Content: I've read the reviews of this hotel and they are all over the map. I spent a week in NYC for Christmas 2002 and stayed here, and didn't have any problems with cleanliness, plumbing, or rudeness, and I'm sorry to see that some customers have had those problems. Maybe I got lucky. My philosophy of a hotel depends on why I am staying somewhere away from home. If I'm in Europe or a big city in the US for pleasure travel, the purpose of the hotel is to sleep and shower in; I don't need a big room to entertain, to get out a notebook, or even to watch TV. The closer your thoughts about hotels are to that, the more you will like the Riverside Towers. While I was there, the clientele was markedly foreign; for example, a group of Japanese women who we decided were college kids on a trip stayed there, along with several European couples. The rooms are small, and so are the bathrooms (if you get a suite, the bathroom is between the two bedrooms). There are some pictures in the "candid traveler" section of this hotel's reviews that look right. Our rooms were clean. I don't think they changed the bedlinens every day but they probably would have if we'd asked for it; the beds were made and we had fresh towels. What I don't see mentioned a lot here is the location of the hotel. You're on 80th Street, about a block and change west of Broadway (and these are the short blocks). Once you hit Broadway, voila, there is Xabar's! Cheap, fantastic breakfast, and good coffee; you can also get gourmet food at the market. (The stray cats in this neighborhood are so lucky because of all the empty caviar tins they leave out after closing.) With regard to the subway, the closest station is, well, very close; I'm trying to remember but I think it's 78th Street but there's a stairwell just at 79th. This gets you to the red lines downtown; it's perhaps 10 minutes to Times Square, for example. I also felt that this motel was safe, and was honestly run. When I first got there, I thought I would have to pay every night we stayed, but when the night receptionist had gotten used to me (i.e. the second night), he told me just to put it on my credit card when we left. I would stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “a bit grubby but a super location”
Reviews.Author: spf
Reviews.Content: was a bit concerned, only read the reviews in depth after booking......... verdict. very cramped room maybe made worse by old large furniture. room 47. smelly noisy a/c. but boy did we need it this weekend. a basic old place that needs a lick of paint and a bit of tlc. as mentioned great location for food and drink, very safe too, too hot for the subway? u can get a cab to say union sq for about $12!? easy walk to central park, lincoln centre, even on a hot day. some desk staff were very helpful but a couple were a bit 'distant' . if u want deluxe go to the W but i'd rather spend the money on seeing the city rather than a luxury carpet.

Reviews.Title: “Its just a place to sleep after all”
Reviews.Author: Bruspotter
Reviews.Content: OK lets be honest about this place. It is not the Ritz. It does smell of bug spray but we saw no bugs during our 2 night stay. The rooms are small but they ARE CLEAN. We had one of the suites which is basically two inter-connecting rooms with a bathroom in between.The bathroom is no bigger than a postage stamp but is good enough for a shower at the end o the day and in the morning. The shower was spotless and powerful. The sheets were crispy clean and the bed comfortable. The carpets were a bit shabby. We had two tv's and two air conditioning units in our suite, plus a refridgerator and microwave.The elavators are very small. The desk staff are very friendly and helpful and always have a smile and say hi. The neighborhood is safe and decent and the subway is less than five minutes away. with the subway you can leave your room and be in Time's Square in 15 minutes. There are numerous deli's, liquor stores, restaurants and other stores just one block away. Zabars is one minute away. If you are a budget-minded tourist and just want a simple, no frills but clean and comfortable place to sleep for a reasonable price, for a couple of nights to see New York, this is the place to make your reservation. If you want a fancy upscale hotel closer to the main attractions, don't come here. All in all, a positive experience, I have no complaints.

Reviews.Title: “Get What You Pay For!”
Reviews.Author: kidsbank
Reviews.Content: We booked this hotel for a long weekend for my son's graduation. After booking we read the reviews. We still decided to keep our resevations and were somewhat surprised. After reading about the pealing paint and cockroaches form hell we did expect the worst. What we encountered was the exact opposite. The room was clean, rugs were worn (but so are carpets in any hotel). The only complaint we had was upon check in, on one of the hottest weekends yet, we did not have ant air conditioning in the rooms. We asked at the desk and were told that the owner has them scheduled to go in later. We overcame and bought fans, which we left with our son, and discovered on the 2nd day the AC was installed for us. Ala in all, a good experience. We are planning another trip there in August and would definitely stay there again!! I recommend it, after all, you are in NYC.. Who stays in their rooms??? RIverside Park is beautiful and the subway is 3 blocks away, and the neighborhood is picture-perfect! We will definitely stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Some rooms better than others?”
Reviews.Author: barbalala
Reviews.Content: I booked this hotel without first looking at the reviews on this web site, and after I saw what others wrote, I have to say I was very worried. Still, I've stayed at really great hotels that have been severely panned by other people, so I know to take these reviews with a grain of salt. That being said, I was extremely disappointed when we were shown our suite (which was apparently the last one available as the hotel was completely booked for the night). It was badly run-down, with an ancient red carpet, peeling paint everywhere and red/brown smudges on the walls (where insects had been smashed?) Still, the bedding was clean, as were the towels and the bathroom, and since the rest of my group (all being extensive budget travelers in our thirties) was okay with it, I reluctantly agreed to stay. The neighbourhood is excellent, with beautiful, upscale apartments/townhouses all around and fantastic places to eat, as well as quiet and extremely safe-feeling, so for those reasons--and the cheap price--I'm happy we chose to stay at this hotel. However, when we came back to the room on the second night, we found three cockroaches in our in-room sink and one in the bathroom. Later, as I was bedding down for the night, one crawled out of a pillowcase that had been stored in the closet. The thing is, I believe the reviews on this site that say their rooms were in great condition (i.e. no peeling paint). I have a feeling it really depends on what room you get. And as far as "gang grafitti" on the walls (which I read in one of the reviews), I highly doubt that, as the rest of the people staying at the hotel all looked completely respectable. Still, I would only recommend this hotel to people who are used to really roughing it. As someone who's roughed it in the past, I still had a pretty hard time with the cockroaches, and the owner really ought to be ashamed about the peeling paint and overall appearance of the rooms (at least ours).

Reviews.Title: “Ignore all the other reviews”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I just spent two nights in this hotel and was terrified before arriving and desperately tried [but failed]to book other accomodations after reading reviews on this site. Needless to say I asked to see the "suite" we booked before presenting our credit card. The friendly desk clerk obliged with no problem. The rooms were small as advertised, but clean. The bathroom was miniscule, but adequate, and spotlessly clean. The beds were extremely comfortable and the pillows were of high quality. There was no sign of any bugs, either cockroaches or bedbugs. Our rooms were freshly painted and there was no sight of peeling paint anywhere. I slept like a baby with the window open. The second night I asked the desk for another blanket and it was on my bed upon my return. The neighborhood is quiet and safe. The subway is two short blocks away, and cabs were easily caught on West End Avenue, a block away. If your plan is to find inexpensive accomodations and are travelling with a friend or with children, the suite at $109/night is unbeatable. The two rooms connected by the bath gave us privacy we could have never had in a standard double room. I will stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Great price for what you get”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Cheap prices, great location and surroundings, and good service. For just a place to sleep it's perfect. It's not the most updated place, but it works for a day trip. It's clean, but it can deffiently use some upkeep and updating.

Reviews.Title: “Lacks cleanliness, comfort, and atmosphere”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I had the opportunity to visit this hotel recently because I continually see advertisements in our Providence Sunday Journal. Friends in RI have wondered what the hotel was really like. I found it to lack cleanliness. The carpets were worn. I saw the inside of a room on the 12th floor. I entered the room into a very small bedroom. In between this bedroom and the other bedroom was a bathroom. I would not recommend this hotel to any of my friends in RI.

Reviews.Title: “Can't decide whether to stay here? Let me help..”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Riverside Tower off 80th in NY on Dec 17-22...or atleast that was how long we intended to stay. Our trip to NYC was not planned that far in advance, so we decided since most places were booked or pretty expensive since it was November, we would opt for a cheaper place. Then we came across Riverside Tower, which i was a little leary about, but figured it couldnt be that bad! I even read reviews on this website and just like many others thought.."well we arent going to ever be in our rooms so who cares!" I couldnt have been more wrong! I went with my fiancee, my sister, and her fiancee. We are all between 23-25 and we collectivly thought, heck, we have lived through college dorms, crappy apartments and in their case "bachelor pads" it couldnt be any worse than that. Well The rooms are smaller than dorms...they were a little bigger than our bed that was in there. There were holes in the walls, bugs, and paint peeling off. Carpet was RED and filthy. The sinks were the wierdest thing i had ever seen! They were an oval shape with the faucet on the left side and it was so small i could not wash my face in it at night...mainly because there was a medcine cabinet directly above the sink so i couldnt get my face over the sink, water went all over me and the floor. We were short 2 pillows and on our way out we asked for two, the incredibly rude lady (which all employess were there) said she would send some up. So of course when we returned there were no pillows and (no surprise here) they were out. So half of us didnt have pillows. The shower was filthy, i wore my flip flops in there and the worst part of all was that there was nothing but a HANDLE LOCK on the door..and its a flimsy door. I can tell you honestly, this place isnt worth another thought. One night it was too cold so we had to stay in the room after about 7pm...we couldnt even all sit in the same room, it was too cramped. Just spend a little bit more and go to hotel pennsylvania, thats were we went to after 3 nights because no one wanted to take anymore showers there or sleep in that nasty place. Trust me, the amount of money you "save" you will be offering double of to get out of there. Feel free to e-mail me, i can tell you even more..

Reviews.Title: “The truth? It's a decent bargain.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: It was with great trepidation that I headed towards the Riverside Tower Hotel from the airport. I read all the reviews and tried to sift out the bogus ones (probably placed by competing hotels) from the real ones. On the whole, it seemed like most people were saying that this hotel was a real bargain, but the rooms were small and the furnishings sparse and worn. But I still couldn't help but wonder if I had made a big mistake (e.g., maybe I was just believing what I wanted to believe). The truth is that upon arrival and settling in, I was greatly relieved. No, there was not any graffiti on the walls. No, there were not bums passed out in the hallways. No, there were not any bed bugs. No, there were not any cockroaches. No, the carpets and bathroom floors were not filthy and did not need to be covered with towels to be safely walked upon. No, the rooms were not the sizes of small closets. All of those statements, I believe, are bogus posts meant to scare potential customers away to the competition. So what was the hotel really like? I think the average assessment that you get from most of the rest of the posts on tripadvisor is correct. In other words, as I said above, you can expect a small room with sparse furnishings in a well-worn building. Those would be the negatives. The positives include the great price (we paid $99 for a suite, which is two small rooms connected by a bathroom) and a great neighborhood (AKA the Upper Westside). I would have to say that my biggest tip for others would be to definitely ask for a suite. The individual rooms are small. Just having two different spaces made a big deal to me psychologically. And I could be in one room quietly watching TV while my wife was napping in the other. I definitely would have felt cooped up otherwise. I also want to reiterate how great is the neighborhood. There are all kinds of great restaurants and stores within easy walking distance, not to mention Central Park as well as the subway. I live smack in the middle of urban Los Angeles, but even I did not want to be staying in the hustle-bustle of Time Square. The Upper Westside is dense, but it's filled with brownstone homes/apartments, where "normal" people live with their children and dogs, etc. It felt good to walk around the neighborhood, which, by the way, is quite safe. And you can even get away from this quite quickly, if that's still too much hustle and bustle for you, by strolling over into Central Park which is just a couple of blocks away. I'll stop here. If you're like me, you'll probably still have some trepidation because you never really know until you get there and see things with your own eyes. But I would recommend the Riverside Tower Hotel as a great bargain in a decent, livable space.

Reviews.Title: “This hotel was fine. Neighborhood great.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Despite the nasty reviews, we thought we'd take a risk and stay at the Riverside Tower. We'd taken the precaution of bringing a list of some other hotels to retreat to if necessary. But really, while a little on the dumpy side, this hotel was fine and our stay was mostly uneventful. We had a suite--two small rooms with a bathroom in between. One room had a single bed with a trundle, an old TV, a chest of drawers, small closet, a dining table and two chairs, sink w/medicine chest, microwave and small fridge. The other had a double bed with chest of drawers, an old TV, smaller closet, and sink w/medicine cabinet. All of this was perfectly fine for our needs, and our daughter had plenty of space to toddle between the rooms. Though one of the elevators smelled like bug spray, the suite was clean enough, not a cockroach in sight. The rug had seen better days and the paint was peeling slightly by the sink. Whatever. We paid $99 and it's an old building--that was one of its charms. There were some problems. The microwave wouldn't come on until I jiggled the electrical cord, and then it heated up items super fast, as though something was desperately wrong with it. I unplugged it when not in use. You can hear the hot water pipes tapping at times, but it wasn't loud enough to impede our sleep. We just kept getting up to check our daughter until we figured out what it was. While this has nothing to do with our room, I thought I'd point out that there was a couple in the lobby who had arrived thinking they had a reservation, but when they got there, the hotel was completely booked. I overheard the staff lamenting someone who "kept doing this no matter what we say." I wondered if it was someone on their reservation staff until my husband pointed out that it was probably an Internet booking service. We don't know who it was but we were glad we'd called three times before departing for NYC to check on our room, probably annoying the staff, but assuring our peace of mind. Food for thought. Back to the room, the biggest problem was the bathroom. It was miniscule with a dreadful, dingy shower--water kept changing temperature--and a low toilet. My husband burned his hand when he, out of curiousity, touched a pipe by the toilet. This was disturbing, especially given the fact that we had our 20 month old with us. They really should label that thing, and with how much McDonald's had to pay out after a woman spilled coffee on her lap, they really ought to consider it. Front desk staff were nice but order your own cab. We ended up paying $60 for a trip to JFK and, I could be wrong, but I think it was because the company they'd found for us rolled up in a Mercedes. Also, do your own research on restaurants. We stepped up to the desk dressed all bummy in jeans and asked to be directed to the best pizza in NYC. We were sent to a frou-frou restaurant where dinner jackets were required. Maybe there was pizza on the menu, but we didn't see it at first glance. But then we were in a hurry to get away from there. We quickly retreated to a pizza joint a few blocks down from the hotel. Speaking of which, the neighborhood was great. Central Park, a great kids's playground, museums and fine shopping were in walking distance and we jumped on the nearby subway to visit Times Square and Harlem. We were at Zabar's, which is a short two-block walk away, at least once a day; they have an incredible selection of groceries and ready-to-eat meals and the prices were reasonable. We weren't disappointed with anything we purchased there, and I wished we were in town longer so we could try more of their offerings. There was a church very close to the hotel that offers a Wed night worship time that we'll check out next time. Overall, we were happy with our stay at the Riverside Tower, and would choose it again. The quarters were cramped, but certainly liveable, and you don't spend much time in your room anyways.

Reviews.Title: “It was 'ok' but I won't stay there agin.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel 2 nights on Sep '05. Nice and helpful stuffs (the guy answer the phone isn’t very nice, but 2 girls at the front desk are great), great location (subway and great restaurants are 2 blocks away), safe/quiet neighborhood. The room is so small, kind of smell and REALLY old- we even found cockroaches in our room. Bring your own slippers- you will need to wear them into bathroom and shower. Even the low price, if I have known the room is this bad, I will try to spend extra $50 at somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “good deal!”
Reviews.Author: powderlux
Reviews.Content: After reading the bad reviews on this site, I was not particularly looking forward to this hotel. However I was very pleasantly surprised, and could not understand the bad reviews at all. The suite (2 people) was quite spacious with a lovely view of the hudson river. It had been freshly painted and was well cleaned on a daily basis. The TV was quite large and the fridge and microwave (both also clean) came to be of great use. Not a single roach in sight either. I would definitely recommend this place to a friend; couldn't believe the low prices, as this is also a very nice location, quite near to a subway stop in a quiet area. Overall, we really enjoyed our stay here. It was a great find!

Reviews.Title: “Best Deal in New York”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I read a good number of the reviews on this site prior to staying at the hotel, and have to say that they strike as somewhat unfair. For 85 dollars in the heart of New York City -- the hotel really couldn't be better located -- one should be prepared for nothing but the most basic accomodations (a bed, and a sink/shower with hot water), and the Riverside Hotel does fine when measured against these standards. Yes, there are holes in the walls of the bathroom. Yes, the rooms are half the size of the bathroom in my studio apartment. But seeing how all anyone really needs when staying in New York is a bed to crash into at 3 in the morning and crawl out of six hours later, I think that the Riverside is a perfectly adequate option for folks traveling alone or as a couple. I think the Riverside deserves an "above average" for providing the only affordable decent lodging in Manhattan.

Reviews.Title: “Stay away !!!!”
Reviews.Author: SabineMetzger
Reviews.Content: Although the surrounding area is great and the low prices are tempting - do not go there !!!!! Our room was small, smelly and full of roaches ( up to fingersize - ough!!!). Lady at the front desk is friendly and helpful, and if you want to listen to strange sounds coming out of the stained carpet all night and if you want to be greeted by all sorts of bugs when you come home from swinging New York: it´s your place ! Pay much less and stay in a nice New Jersey hotel and invest in bus tickets, but do not go to Riverside Tower Hotel !!!!!
